provenance.textSnippet:
Grade ECOG
0 Fully Active, able to carry on all pre-disease performance without restriction.
provenance.rationale: This is the explicit definition for Grade 0 of the ECOG Performance Status scale provided in a table in the protocol.

provenance.textSnippet: 1 Restricted in physically strenuous activity but ambulatory and able to carry out work of a light or sedentary nature, e.g., light housework, office work.
provenance.rationale: This is the explicit definition for Grade 1 of the ECOG Performance Status scale provided in a table in the protocol.

provenance.textSnippet: 2 Ambulatory and capable of all self-care but unable to carry out any work activities. Up and about more than 50% of waking hours.
provenance.rationale: This is the explicit definition for Grade 2 of the ECOG Performance Status scale provided in a table in the protocol.

provenance.textSnippet: 3 Capable of only limited self-care, confined to bed or chair more than 50% of waking hours.
provenance.rationale: This is the explicit definition for Grade 3 of the ECOG Performance Status scale provided in a table in the protocol.

provenance.textSnippet: 4 Completely disabled. Cannot carry on any self-care. Totally confined to bed or chair.
provenance.rationale: This is the explicit definition for Grade 4 of the ECOG Performance Status scale provided in a table in the protocol.

expansions.rationale: The protocol provides an explicit table on page 46 that decomposes the ECOG Performance Status scale into its constituent grades (0-4) and their specific definitions.

provenance.textSnippet: A CT scan of the full chest and abdomen (with image of liver and adrenal glands) will be used in the evaluation of tumor responses, as per Table 2
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly states that a CT scan will be the primary method used for the evaluation of tumor responses.

provenance.textSnippet: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can be conducted in cases where local laws/requirements mandate, but should have Sponsor approval prior to performing the MRI.
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly mentions MRI as an alternative imaging modality for tumor assessments under specific conditions.

provenance.textSnippet: A CT scan of the full chest and abdomen (with image of liver and adrenal glands) will be used in the evaluation of tumor responses
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly defines the chest as a body region to be imaged for tumor assessment.

provenance.textSnippet: A CT scan of the full chest and abdomen (with image of liver and adrenal glands) will be used in the evaluation of tumor responses
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly defines the abdomen (including liver and adrenal glands) as a body region to be imaged for tumor assessment.

provenance.textSnippet: A baseline MRI (or CT if MRI is contraindicated) of the brain is to be performed on any subject with signs or symptoms suggesting CNS involvement by tumor.
provenance.rationale: The protocol specifies that a brain scan (MRI or CT) is a required component of tumor assessment for subjects with CNS symptoms.

provenance.textSnippet: Radiographic information will be collected to determine response according to the Response Evaluation Criteria In Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1.
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly states that RECIST version 1.1 criteria will be used to determine tumor response.

provenance.textSnippet: 10 mm caliper measurement by clinical exam
provenance.rationale: Clinical exam with caliper measurement is explicitly listed as a method for assessing measurable lesions under the RECIST criteria.

provenance.textSnippet: Cytology and histology can be used to differentiate between partial response (PR) and complete response (CR) in rare cases.
provenance.rationale: The protocol specifies that cytology and histology are methods that can be used to confirm tumor response in certain situations.

expansions.rationale: The protocol explicitly defines the components of Tumor Assessments, including the imaging modalities (CT, MRI), body regions to be scanned (chest, abdomen, brain), the evaluation criteria (RECIST v1.1), and other assessment methods (Clinical Exam, Cytology/Histology).

components.name: NCCN-Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) Lung Symptom Index-17 (NFLSI-17)

provenance.textSnippet: To assess the subject's health-related quality of life and symptoms, two questionnaires will be administered: the NCCN-Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) Lung Symptom Index-17 (NFLSI-17)
provenance.rationale: This questionnaire is explicitly named as one of the two instruments used for the Quality of Life Assessment.

provenance.textSnippet: To assess the subject's health-related quality of life and symptoms, two questionnaires will be administered: the NCCN-Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) Lung Symptom Index-17 (NFLSI-17) questionnaire and the European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D-5L).
provenance.rationale: This questionnaire is explicitly named as one of the two instruments used for the Quality of Life Assessment.

expansions.rationale: The protocol explicitly defines that Quality of Life (QoL) will be assessed using two specific questionnaires: NFLSI-17 and EQ-5D-5L, as stated on pages 9 and 50.

provenance.textSnippet: Approximately 3 mL of blood will be collected by venipuncture for veliparib concentrations at 0 hours (just before morning dose of veliparib) and other timepoints as specified per Table 4.
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly states that blood samples will be collected to measure 'veliparib concentrations' as part of the pharmacokinetic specimen collection.

provenance.textSnippet: Plasma concentrations of veliparib metabolite(s) may be determined using validated or non-validated methods.
provenance.rationale: The protocol explicitly states that plasma concentrations of veliparib metabolite(s) may be determined as part of the pharmacokinetic measurement methods.

expansions.rationale: The protocol explicitly defines two analytes to be measured for pharmacokinetic assessment: 'veliparib' and 'veliparib metabolite(s)' in Section 5.3.2 on page 53.
